reviews.title: Step back in time - but with an updated twist
text: Fantastic little find.
An old school, single screen cinema with limited daily screenings.
The first film we saw was the recently released Elvis movie, and will be returning next week to view a 40th anniversary screening of The Texas Chainsaw Massacre - a fun way to spend the evening.

reviews.title: Old Fox Comes Alive!
text: On New Year’s Eve, my wife and I, with a dear friend, thoroughly enjoyed watching Bohemian Rhapsody, the current movie about Queen, the fabled rock group, featuring the highly talented and very entertaining Freddie Mercury. As a threatre venue, the Fox on Queen Street, in the Beach area of Toronto, is virtually unparalleled in our city.

Originally opened in 1914 to show the then new phenomenon of moving pictures in black and white with no sound, this iconiv venue has been refurbished throughout and now features comfortable, reclining seats (not the original hard wooden ones), a much larger & wider screen, and a modern sound system (suited to accomodate today’s high-tech movies). The theatre’s narrow foyer retains much of its original charm with the original, tiny ticket booth at the entrance, movie posters on the walls, a small candy counter along one side, two tiny washrooms (with modern toilets & wash basind) at the far end, just outside the rear of the seating area itself.

Tickets are moderately-priced at about $10 per person, $8 for Seniors & Thestre Members. Entrance can be paid on-site or on-line in advance, which luckily I had done as there was a huge lineup outside when we arrived at 6:45 for the 7 pm start! As we moved inside, we heard an usher announce: ”Sorry, folks, but the threatre is sold out!

Warching the fascinating bio-pic-style movie was a terrific way to usher out the old year, as the featue on the screen harkened nostalgicly back a by-gone, earlier era of hard-rock extravagancas of the 1970s and 1980s. Many in the audience, like us, were very familiar with the music of Queen and sang along with the full-bore lyrics delivered masterfully and with stylized abandon by the Freddie Mercury character. At several points, but especially near the end of the movie, which recreated the group’s performance at the now, world-famous charity concert at Wembley Stadium in London to raise funds to help the starving people of Bangladesh, the Fox audience clapped and cheered wildly, as if we actually were participating in that historic event in person! We felt a sense of magic in reliving, through film, that once-in-a-lifetime musical event!
For all three of us, seeing and experiencing this movie at the Fox Threatre will be a New Year’s Eve that we will long remember.

reviews.title: Local fav
text: My gf will now not go to Imagine Cinemas (formerly Rainbow) as she says the seats are uncomfortable.  This old theatre has very comfy seats in an old theatre.  The popcorn is awesome and you can have booze as well!  My gf and I renewed our annual membership for 3rd straight year.  Very affordable compared to the larger cinema chains.

reviews.title: One of the Best Cinemas
text: You don't see many small theatres that offer so much. It is like a step back into the 50's when going to see a film was a big event. Great, older style comfortable seats and a wonderful concession stand, offering alcohol. This venue makes your viewing even more enjoyable!

reviews.title: Cinema Magic
text: Love this place. A time capsule of movie watching. Its affordable, great comfy seating, it sells beer and wine. No blaring previews. Long may it run!

reviews.title: The real deal...a Beach classic
text: This classic neighbourhood cinema has it all...it's walkable, serves beer, mellow, cheap, and reminds you when film was cinema and neighbours were friends. The crowd is a bit grey or young if it's a kiddie film, but I love this place.

reviews.title: Classic
text: I have been coming to this theatre for years.  I like the old school feel and the popcorn rocks.  Pricing is better than the chain theatres.  I bought a membership which is a no brainer of you will go twice a year.  My girlfriend doesn't want to go to other theatres and claims these are the comfiest seats of all - they slightly recline.

reviews.title: Fox Theatre, the longest running cinema in Canada. 1914-2016
text: Still operating and keeping the name since 1937, the movie house is integral part of Beaches neighbourhood. Founded by Arthur Webster as 'The Pastime'. In the time, when many movie houses in Toronto are closing, they must be doing something right, to keep the doors open. I have been in Fox many times in the 1980's, but not the least 20 years. In the meanwhile they renovated (2007), keeping with nostalgia design, but with comfortable chairs.

reviews.title: One of the best cinemas you can find.
text: Had to review this since nobody else has.

Honestly, the Fox Theatre is my favourite cinema in Toronto. It's not without its flaws which I'll start with. Firstly, this ain't a place to catch the newest releases. They catch movies on their second run and the more popular the movie is in big theatres, the longer its going to take to make it to the Fox Theatre. I remember the Avengers almost coming out on DVD before making it to the Fox! They only have 1 screen so it is hard to keep up sometimes!

It's location may be offputting to some of you, it's right at the end of the Beaches on the east side of Toronto. the Streetcar along Queen Street is usually the best way to get there by public transport.

But it is worth the trip, especially for a movie you want to see. For a start, some of the smaller, perhaps more artsy movies regularly make it to the Fox but they don't ignore the blockbusters either. The last movie I saw there was for example The Dark Knight Rises but I've also seen movies like Drive, Moonrise Kingdom, The Raid.

The decor of the place is terrific, it's got an old style cinema decor with a ticket booth outside provided the weather is ok for queuing and the lobby leads into the screen without any doors in the way. It's a warm welcoming building to anyone tired of the same looking multiplexes.

You may think a one screen cinema in an old building may not be the best but the screenings are all in crisp Digital(if shot in Digital), look fantastic and the sound is at a high level and quality. They also provide 3D which I haven't experienced myself there. Seats are comfy and even recline a bit.

It's not a rip off either, a large popcorn(which is yum) and coke is under 10 bucks and a ticket is about 10 bucks too, reasonable in this day and age. They also provide memberships which give you a few bucks off the ticket price and 10% off all snacks and drinks. Worth it if you go a few times, the membership is ten bucks.
All in all, if you are a movie lover and go to the cinema regularly, you will love The Fox.

reviews.title: A neighbourhood classic
text: All beach dwellers know about this gem of a Theatre on Queen Street East.  At over 100 years old, and Canada's Longest Running Theatre, it is a must visit.  We are members, which will net you great discounts on both the movie tickets, and the concession stand.

The seats are still plush red velvet, and the screen still has a curtain.  You can see the old movie equipment at the back.  Join them now, for their 80's week, just in case you missed some classics in the theatre  :)

reviews.title: Nostalgic theatre!
text: A wonderful walk down memory lane, in this 103 year old theatre.  It has been restored beautifully and is warm, welcoming, quaint, comfy and a must visit.  We watched  3D movie and enjoyed some popcorn in great surroundings.  Staff are delightful.  Recommend you purchase a membership and stop in frequently.  We will.

reviews.title: My go-to cinema in Toronto
text: I love the FOX. It's a great neighbourhood theatre showing a nice variety of films. The seats are comfortable, the popcorn is incredibly good, the staff are wonderful and nice, and they have great membership prices on tickets and concessions. Oh, and if you're feeling like it, you can enjoy a beer or wine with your movie. If you haven't been to the Fox, you should go.

reviews.title: A touch of the past with modern comfort
text: This neighborhood movie theatre is a little jewel. The seats are are oh so comfortable. The 2nd run movies are a great chance to catch up on hits one might have missed.
Price is right, even better with annual membership.
Love the fact that wine is now served as well!

reviews.title: One Giant Screen - affordable.
text: Takes you back in time to a simpler movie going experience. You can shop or dine at a large array of shops and restaurants in the Beach area. The world famous Goof chinese restaurant is right across the street.  Then take in a movie with comfy seating. You won't get a headache just going through the lobby. Very old school. line up for ticket. line up for popcorn and drink. Go see a movie. All very quiet and civilized. I have been going to The Fox since the early 80's and love it. Try it once, and I'm pretty sure you will come back. Buy a membership and the price of a movie becomes totally affordable again.

reviews.title: Brilliant night out
text: We were encouraged to have a night at the movies whilst staying with family in Toronto. The Fox Theater celebrated it's 100th anniversary this year apparently so we thought we would give it a go. The place is fantastic and reeks of history. Tickets were only CAN$11 each and drinks and snacks were not over priced especially compared to the price of going to the multi plex cinemas back in the UK  where a second mortgage is needed to buy drinks and snacks. Seats are extremely comfortable, a good sized screen and overall very clean. A good value evening's entertainment and definitely recommended

reviews.title: Loved It
text: Bought 2 tickets, 1 large popcorn and 2 drinks online from Groupon for $15. What a deal! We live in the suburbs, but we had a great time at the Beaches, and we loved the feel of the Fox Theatre. It has so much charm. We saw a newly released movie; the place was almost full. It is a licensed theatre, they had wine/popcorn combos for sale...

I will go back. I remember the Runnymede Cinema and the theatre at Jane and Bloor that was converted to a Chapters Bookstore. I much prefer these kinds of theatres to the multiplexes that we now have.

reviews.title: Local Institution
text: The Fox has been around a long time and is worth a visit - the theatre is old and charming with okay prices and delicious buttery popcorn!  Movies are a combination of current, second run and foreign gems and you can usually find something interesting to see there.

reviews.title: Old-Style Theatre Experience
text: Sure ... the new multi-plex theatres have lots of bells and whistles but who needs the crowds and the inflated prices?  The Fox is a small, old-style, repertory theatre with lower prices, comfortable seats and a great atmosphere. If you'll be in the area on a regular basis, purchase a one-year membership and get a discount on your admission and concession purchases.

reviews.title: Retro love.
text: Just enjoyed our first visit to this charming vintage theatre.

Chairs provide generous padding, width and leg room. It has lovely quirks - washrooms accessed from the theatre, so you can hear what you're missing; pipes prone to calamitous creaking and popping, and the old-style school bus room geometry (long and thin). From the rear, we could see well, although I missed a couple of lines of dialogue.

It would have been sweet had the exterior ticket booth been in operation, but frigidly cold tonight! $11 for an adult admission; $10 for members I think. If we lived nearby, I'd consider the membership.
